task.title: Run and Connect to an Instance
task.shortdesc: This task explains how to run and connect to an instance.

context.p: To launch and conenct to an instance:

info.codeblock: IMAGE eki-5F663C59 testbucket/vmlinuz-2.6.32-5-amd64.manifest.xml 449455269925 available public x86_64 kernel instance-store IMAGE eki-2E963B03 tmp0hpdstttmi/vmlinuz-2.6.28-11-generic.manifest.xml 000000000001 available public i386 kernel instance-store IMAGE emi-A6D3365C tmpu9kzz13enx/ubuntu.9-04.x86-64.img.manifest.xml 449455269925 available public i386 machine eki-2E963B03 eri-E3263C85 instance-store IMAGE eri-E3263C85 tmpqnx9gm08oa/initrd.img-2.6.28-11-generic.manifest.xml 000000000001 available public i386 ramdisk instance-store IMAGE eri-A7A63A1D testbucket/initrd.img-2.6.32-5-amd64.manifest.xml 449455269925 available public x86_64 ramdisk instance-store IMAGE emi-F0E33C52 testbucket/euca-centos-2012.1.14-x86_64.manifest.xml 449455269925 available public x86_64 machine eki-5F663C59 eri-A7A63A1D instance-store
info.p: For this example, we will use the last image in the list, emi-F0833C52.

step.cmd: Create a key pair using the euca-add-keypair command. This command will store the public half of the key pair and keep it available for your Eucalyptus cloud instances, and will output the private half of the key pair. Save this output to a file for future use, as in the following example:

info.note: If you've already added a keypair, you can skip this step.

Run the instance with the euca-run-instances command, specifying the appropriate image ID and the name of the key pair you just created. For example:

stepresult.p: This will return output similar to the following:
stepresult.codeblock: RESERVATION r-CCE33FC0 449455269925 default INSTANCE i-68A24092 emi-F0E33C52 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 pending mytestkey 0 m1.small 2012-05-17T10:36:46.232Z PARTI00 eki-5F663C59 eri-A7A63A1D monitoring-disabled 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 instance-store
stepresult.p: Note that the initial state of the instance is 'pending' while the instance is being created.

step.cmd: After a few moments, check to see if your instance is available for use yet by using the euca-describe-instances command:

stepresult.p: When the instance is ready, this command will return output similar to the following:
stepresult.codeblock: RESERVATION r-CCE33FC0 449455269925 default INSTANCE i-68A24092 emi-F0E33C52 192.168.9.91 10.93.7.76 running mytestkey 0 m1.small 2012-05-17T10:36:46.232Z PARTI00 eki-5F663C59 eri-A7A63A1D monitoring-disabled 192.168.9.91 10.93.7.76 instance-store
stepresult.p: Note that the instance is now listed as 'running', and there's now an IP address - in this example, 192.168.9.91. You can use this IP address to connect to the instance.

stepresult.p: This command returns output similar to the following:
stepresult.codeblock: Warning: Permanently added '192.168.9.91' (RSA) to the list of known hosts. Last login: Thu May 17 03:39:58 2012 from eucahost-9-91.eucalyptus -bash-3.2#

taskbody.result: Congratulations! You've now successfully launched an instance and connected to it with SSH.
